Product selectivity depends on many reaction parameters like solvent, temperature and halogenating agent in addition to the composition and structure of the zeolite catalyst. Even though, zeolites, in general, are unstable in the presence of the halogenoacids liberated during halogenation, recent developments, like the use of L-zeolite, may lead to the industrial use of zeolites in halogenation reactions. Introduction Zeolite catalysts are used extensively in the petroleum refining and petrochemical industries for various cracking, hydrocracking, isomerization, alkylation, dehydro- genation and rearrangement reactions of hydrocarbons and their derivatives. During the last decade, a beginning has also been made in their use as selective oxidation catalysts using H202 as the oxidant [ 1 ]. The use of zeolite catalysts in the synthesis of fine chemicals is an interesting area of application of growing importance in recent years [2]. By contrast, the utility of zeolite catalysts in the synthesis of halogen-containing organic compounds has not been explored in sufficient detail, especially, when it is recalled that production of halo-organics constitutes a signif- icant segment of the organic chemical industry. Commodity chemicals like vinyl chloride monomer (for the manufacture of PVC) and the hydrofluorocarbons (CFC' s, HFCs etc) and intermediates like chlorotoluenes are widely used material and the use of solid catalysts, like the zeolites, in their manufacture may lead to better process options. Most of the industrial halogenations of organic compounds are, at present, performed by free halogens either in the absence of catalysts (hal- ogenation of aliphatics or side chains in aromatic hydrocarbons) or in the presence of Lewis acid catalysts such as the halides of aluminum and iron ( aromatic nuclear halogenation). These state-of-the-art catalysts have certain shortcomings: ( 1 ) Strict anhydrous conditions are required to avoid corrosion problems; (2) the operation has to be carried out in the absence of light to avoid side chain halogenation; and (3) the halides of iron and aluminum, being strong Lewis acids, also catalyze other undesirable side reactions like alkyl isomerization and transalkylation or displacement of the alkyl group by the halogen. The latter are accentuated by increase in the temperature, the degree of substitution on the adjacent carbon atom and the acidity of the catalyst. An additional major handicap of the Lewis acid catalysts like FeC13 or A1C13, is the difficulty of their disposal, after use in the halogenation reaction, in an environmentally acceptable manner. The use of solid catalysts in halogenation processes will avoid corrosion and disposal problems. Work-up procedures to isolate and recover the desired product will also be easier leading to simpler and cleaner process routes. In addition, if zeolites are used as the solid catalysts, one may anticipate that desired changes in selectivity (enhanced .para selectivity in nuclear halogenation of aromatics, for example) may be achieved. Irreversible damage caused to the zeolite structure by hydrogen halides, especially when arenes are halogenated, is a major problem to be solved before zeolites can be used in industrial halogenation processes to a significant extent. After a brief review of the basic principles of halogenation reactions and the properties of commonly used halogenating agents (Section 2), fluorination, chlo- rination, bromination and iodination reactions over zeolite catalysts are discussed in detail (Section 3). Both literature reports and unpublished results from the P. Ratnasamy et al. /Applied Catalysis A." General 135 (1996) 25-55 27 authors' laboratory are reviewed. The structural stability of zeolites, during halo- genation reactions, is analyzed in Section 4. 2. Halogenation and halogenating agents A comprehensive account of the properties of halogens and their intermediate derivatives is given by Downs and Adams [ 3 ] and electrophilic halogenation is reviewed by de la Mare [4]. Only a brief summary of the salient features of halogenation reactions and halogenating agents will be given in this section. The fluorine molecule, because of its low bond strength, is very reactive. It readily dissociates into atoms which react with organic molecules in an exothermic manner to form hydrogen fluoride and fluorocarbons. Chlorine and bromine are generally less indiscriminate in their behaviour and show progressively diminishing reactiv- ity. Iodine is even less reactive than bromine, partly because it forms rather weak bonds to other elements and partly because it is large enough to cause steric congestion in the products of many organic reactions. The halogen derivatives of the alkanes (alkyl halides) may be prepared by a variety of methods: ( 1 ) By direct halogenation i.e. by substitution reactions of the alkanes brought about by light, heat or catalysts; In photohalogenations, (especially chlorination or bromination) carried out at room temperature in the presence of light, the reaction takes place by a free-radical chain mechanism, the initiation being brought about by the formation of halogen atoms by the absorption of light. The chain reaction may terminate by adsorption of the halogen atoms on the walls of the containing vessel, by combination of two halogen atoms or by combination of a halogen atom with an alkyl radical. In both photo- and thermal halogenations, no carbon skeleton rearrangement occurs at low temperatures and halogenations beyond the monohalo derivative may be suppressed by controlling the ratio of halogen to alkane. The order of ease of substitution is tertiary hydrogen > second- ary > primary. At 300 with reactions in the vapour phase, the relative rates of substitution of primary, secondary and tertiary hydrogen atoms are 1.00:3.25:4.43 [5 ]. As the temperature rises above 300, these relative rates of substitution tend to become equal. An increase in pressure has a similar effect, in that it increases the rate of primary substitution; (2) by the addition of halogen acids to an alkene and (3) by direct chlorination of alkanes using sulphuryl chloride in the presence of light. Halogenation of aromatic compounds can lead to ( 1 ) addition compounds, (2) nuclear substitution products and (3) side-chain substitution products. When treated with C12 or Br2 in the presence of sunlight, benzene forms the addition compounds C6H6C16 and C6H6Br6, respectively. Nuclear substitution occurs in the presence of Lewis acid catalysts, like AIC13 or FeC13, by an electrophilic substitution mechanism. Nuclear halogenations can also be carried out with hypochlorous or hypobromous acid. Side chain substitution is favoured by high temperature and 28 P. Fluorination of organic compounds can be carried out by (1) molecular fluorine (F2), (2) fluoroxy compounds (hypofluorites such as F.OC (CF3) 3, (FO) 2CF2 and F.OC ( F3 ) (3) XeF2 (4) perchloryl fluoride (FCIO3) and (5) metallic fuorides (A1F3, CrF3, AgF2, CoF3, MnF3, CoF4, PbF4 etc). The latter (metallic fluorides) have assumed a greater importance in recent years in the quest for a catalyst for the preparation of hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) as replacement for the chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs). Apart from molecular chlorine (C12), other popular chlorination agents include hypochlorous acid, t-butyl hypochlorite, sulphuryl chloride and metallic chlorides like InC12 and SbC15. Similarly apart from Br2, brominations can also be carried out using hypobromous acid (HOBr), bromine acetate (BrOAc), t-butyl hypobromite and N-bromosuccinimide. The iodine molecule, I2 is the least reactive of all the molecular halogens in effecting addition to or substitution in organic compounds. Apart from I2, other iodinating agents like iodine chloride (mainly for aromatic substitutions) and iodine acetate are also used, commonly, as iodination agents. 3. Halogenation over zeolite catalysts The beneficial effects of solid surfaces on the rates of halogenation reactions were observed more than 75 years ago. Stewart and Edlund [6] as well as Norrish [7] and Williums [8] studying the bromination of ethylene on glass showed that the polarity of the glass surface enhanced significantly the rates of bromination. Studies in halogenation over zeolites are of more recent vintage, starting from the early seventies. H61derich et al. have reviewed the halogenation of arenes over zeolite catalysts [9]. There are several features common to all halogenation reactions over zeolites which should be noted before discussing individual halogenations. Zeolites have not been proven to provide any advantage over other high surface area material (like silica) in those halogenations which proceed by a free radical mechanism. These include halogenation of side chains in aromatics and aliphatic compounds. It may be anticipated that electrophilic halogenations and especially nuclear halo- genation of aromatic hydrocarbons may advantageously be carried out in zeolites if shape selective products are desired. Chlorination over zeolites 4.1. Molecular chlorine as the chlorinating agent Molecular chlorine is the traditional reagent for chlorinating aromatic com- pounds. However, in the absence of added catalysts, it reacts readily in an electro- philic manner only with activated aromatic compounds. Weakly activated or non-activated substrates are generally reacted with C12 in the presence of a Lewis acid such as A1C13 or FeC13. The Lewis acid complexes the chlorine to form a highly polarized species, which, in its extreme form, may be represented as a chlorinium salt (C1 + FeC14 ). It is this highly polarized complex which is thought to be the active electrophilic reagent. Levina et al. [ 13] were one of the first to use zeolites in the halogenation of benzene. The zeolite contained Fe3 + ions in cation-exchange positions. The com- position of the product was not mentioned. In 1974 Van Dijk et al. [ 14] reported the interaction of aromatic compounds, preadsorbed from CC14 solution in the pores of NaX, CaX or Ca-Fe-X, with molecular C12 or Br2. An excess of zeolite (by wt. ) was used so that more than 95% of the substrate was adsorbed on the zeolite. After reaction with the halogen at 298 K, the zeolite was separated from the solutions and destroyed with acid and the reaction products were extracted and analyzed by gas-liquid chromatography (GLC). Structural stability of zeolites during halogenation reactions The utility of zeolite catalysts in industrial halogenations, especially in the liquid phase, depends on their reusability in many cycles of reaction. If the quantity of the catalyst (g/g of substrate) is low, say less than 2 to 3% (w/w), it may be economically viable to use fresh samples of the catalyst for each batch of reaction, in the manufacture of specialty chemicals with a high product value. In general, it is desirable to recover and recycle the catalyst. The results reviewed in the previous sections establish the feasibility of using zeolites to carry out highly selective halogenation of organic substrates. By contrast, there are very few systematic studies devoted to evaluating the structural stability of zeolites during halogenation reactions, especially those using molecular halogen as the halogenating agent. A priori, one would expect that the hydrogen halide liberated during the reaction would (1) alter the chemical composition and crystallinity of the zeolite (by removal of A1 from the lattice framework positions) and (2) replace the non- framework cations (like the alkali/alkaline earth cations) by protons. The severity of the consequence of these two phenomena on product distribution and catalyst recycle is likely to vary with the type of zeolite, the halogenating agent, the nature of the solvent and the presence of additives which 'fix' the hydrogen halide formed during the reaction thereby minimizing the damage to the solid zeolite catalyst. Conclusions Halogenation over solid catalysts, in general and zeolite catalysts, in particular, has many advantages. There is great potential and possibility for the use of zeolite catalysts in nuclear halogenation reactions (especially chlorination and bromina- tion) of aromatics in the liquid phase instead of the Lewis acid catalysts (like A1C13 and FeC13) used at present. The use of zeolites in such cases leads to enhanced yields of the para isomer thereby lowering the formation of byproducts and cost of separation. There is a need for a better understanding of the mechanism of halo- genation over zeolite catalysts in the liquid phase. Compared to the wealth of information available on halogenation in the homogeneous, gaseous and liquid phases, our knowledge about the details of solid catalyzed halogenation is meagre. An additional prerequisite for the greater use of zeolites in such applications is the solution, to the problem of physical and structural damage to the zeolite by the P. The use of acid-resistant zeolites (like mordenite, L etc.) can in some circumstances lead to viable solutions.
